title: 110_s2455
content: The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title. Additional emergency CDBG funding is provided. The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" authorizes $1 billion for assistance to States, cities, and counties for housing foreclosure impacts and economic development. Funds can be used for foreclosure-related activities and rental assistance for individual renters. Counseling services are exempt from the limitation on fund use. Under the "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007," funds appropriated can be provided to individual homeowners for foreclosure prevention purposes, including refinancing assistance and loans. The funds can also be given directly to certified housing counseling services approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 3 of the Act increases the public services requirement cap from 15% to 25%. SEC. 4 states that at least 50% of the funds must benefit low- and moderate-income individuals. SEC. 5 outlines plans and reports. SEC. 5 of the Act requires States, metropolitan cities, or urban counties to submit a comprehensive plan for the use of funds and quarterly reports to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 6 discusses waivers. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate the use of funds, excluding fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and environmental requirements. Waivers must align with the overall purpose of the statute. Additionally, the Secretary may waive the 50 percent requirement upon request from a State, metropolitan city, or urban county. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive certain requirements, such as the 50 percent requirement and public service cap, upon request from a State, metropolitan city, or urban county if a compelling need is demonstrated. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register at least 5 days before taking effect. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can grant waivers for certain requirements, which must be reviewed and reauthorized every 2 years. The Secretary must notify the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations of any waivers granted or denied at least 5 days before the decision is made. SEC. 7. Noncompliance with community development requirements under this Act will be subject to the provisions of section 111 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. SEC. 8. The Comptroller General will conduct an audit of all funds appropriated under this Act and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees. SEC. 9. Reports will be required as part of the oversight process. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must report quarterly to the Senate and House Committees on the use of funds, including the number of households receiving counseling and rental assistance, outcomes of assistance activities, certified housing counseling services, steps taken to prevent fraud and abuse.
